title: Can you give an example for a number which is both normal and uncomputable? - Quora

response.answer_text: Chaitin's constant is uncomputable and normal. Normality follows from its uncompressibility or “algorithmic randomness.” The shortest program to print NN bits of Chaitin’s constant (not the whole thing, that would be impossible) is itself N−O(1)N−O(1) bits. If the number were not normal, we could use Huffman encoding to do better than this bound by representing more common bit-sequences with shorter strings of bits.
